Executive Summary:

The SEA3 Providence facility was originally designed and constructed by Chicago Bridge & Iron Company and is a refrigerated LPG storage facility protected from overpressure by vacuum relief valves.  The original facility design was based on American Petroleum Institute (API) Standard 2510  Design and Construction of LPG Installations and the storage vessel design was based on API 620 - Design and Construction of Large, Welded, Low-Pressure Storage Tanks.  The AST is a double walled insulated tank designed for an internal pressure of 1.5 psig at a nominal temperature of -50 Fahrenheit (F) and is insulated with 21-inches of loose fill perlite insulation and 3-inches of fiberglass insulation.   The original tank foundation design was undertaken by Haley & Aldrich, Inc. consulting engineers.   Anchor bars embedded in the concrete foundation are provided to transmit the tank uplift loads to the foundation. The bars are not welded to the tank and are attached by means of a bracket which will allow for take-up of any slack or settlement which might occur during the initial hydrostatic testing of the tank. The roof of the tank is insulated with blown in mineral wool or perlite insulation.   The tank shell plates were designed for the internal pressure plus the static head due to the weight of the LPG product. One-quarter-inch (1/4) thick bottom segmental plates, butt welded from both sides are used immediately beneath the tank shell.   The double walled tank has an outer steel vapor barrier. This includes a double bottom arrangement wherein the load bearing insulation is installed between the two bottoms. 

1.	Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies:

Sea-3 has conducted an extensive recommissioning project that improved the terminals safety, equipment and policies and procedures to meet our standards and those of the EPA, OSHA, US Coast Guard as well as local and State of Rhode Island requirements.  Sea-3 management and staff are s

trongly committed to employee, public and environmental, health and safety.  Our commitment is demonstrated by the improved design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance and employee training associated with the processes at Providence Terminal.  It is Sea-3's policy to implement appropriate controls to eliminate or prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, our response activities are coordinated with Rhode Island Hazardous Material Planning District 5.  Our prevention program and response will help minimize the release and its impacts.  

2.  Stationary Source & Regulated Substances Handled: 

Our terminal's primary activity is the receipt, storage, and shipment of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG).  There are two (2) regulated substances held at above both EPA and OSHA threshold quantities are present at our terminal.  These substances are propane and ethyl mercaptan (ethane thiol).  Both are listed as flammable.  Propane is a gas and ethyl mercaptan is a liquid.  Propane is received as a refrigerated liquid by marine vessels, stored on-site and transformed to a liquid under pressure.  It is loaded in to trucks for distribution in the Providence area and other nearby states.  Ethyl mercaptan is used to odorize the propane delivered to trucks for safety purposes.  Both compounds are classified as flammable under 40 CFR Part 68.  No compounds classified as toxic are stored or used at the terminal in amounts above their threshold quantities.  Details on the amount of flammable materials stored on the terminal site are contained in the RMP data elements.  

3.  Release Scenarios:

The worst-case release scenario submitted for Program 3 flammable substances as a class involve a catastrophic release from storage tanks.  The scenario involves the release of the contents of the large refrigerated propane storage tank, which contains the largest single quantity of flammable material at the terminal.  The Environmental Protection

Agency's RMP*Comp program was used to calculate the distance to a 1 psi overpressure endpoint for the calculated release.  The alternative release scenario submitted for Program 3 flammable substances involves a release from Storage and Transfer.  The release is assumed to result in a Vapor Cloud Explosion.  This scenario is based on the rupture of a 3-inch truck loading line and assumes that active measures (hydrocarbon detectors and automatic shut-off devices) stop the flow within 20-seconds.  The maximum amount of propane vented is assumed to be involved in a vapor cloud explosion.  Details on the alternate case scenario are contained in the RMP registration data elements.  

4.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program & the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:  

The Sea-3 terminal has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 and 29 CFR Part 1910-119.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that was revised, implemented and are currently in place at the Providence, RI terminal.  

4.1  Process Safety Information:

Sea-3 maintains a record or Process Safety Information  (PSI) that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all applicable processes.    

4.2  Process Hazard Analysis:

Our terminal conducts studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The HAZOP methodology is primarily used to carry out these analyses.  Hazard analysis revalidations are conducted to review the previous hazard analysis and to review modifications made to the terminal since the last hazard analysis.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified, trained personnel with expertise in: engineering, process operations.   The last PHA revalidation was completed on February 14, 2024.      

4.3  Operating Procedures:

The operating procedures (OPs)

are revalidated at regular intervals of not more than five (5) years or as needed.  Any findings related to the process hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.  Sea-3 maintains written OPs to ensure safe operations.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily available at our terminal ID:  100000175981; Sea-3 Providence terminal staff are involved in the processes.   OPs are routinely updated when required and were last reviewed and updated on January 1, 2024.

4.4  Training:
 
Sea-3 has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years, and more frequently as needed.  

4.5  Mechanical Integrity:

Sea-3 carries out maintenance checks, calibrations, inspections, and tests on process equipment to ensure proper, safe operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks include, among others: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps, valves, gas detectors, flame detectors, and temperature and pressure switches.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

4.6  Management of Change:

Written procedures are in place at Sea-3 to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures under the Management of Change (MOC) procedure.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modificatio

n in process conditions are made aware of and are offered training to deal with the modification.  

4.7  Pre-Startup Reviews:

Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice by Sea-3.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, installation and operating or maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.  We use a comprehensive checklist of either new or modified processes.
 
4.8  Compliance Audits:

Sea-3 conducts compliance audits   (CAs) to confirm our program meets RMP, PSM and good engineering practices.  An audit was conducted prior to recommissioning the terminal and will be carried out at least every three (3) years.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits will be addressed and implemented as soon as possible to improve compliance with the requirements of the RMP and PSM rules.    The last CA was completed on March 20, 2023.

4.9  Incident Investigation:

Sea-3 investigates any incident that results in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the cause(s) leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions needed to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of five (5) years.

4.10  Employee Participation:

Sea-3 believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a life critical team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the terminal's implementation of the RMP rule.  The employees at the terminal are involved in the implementation of accident prevention program, including participation in the PHA, in the development of OPs and in the MOC process.   Employee involvement

and participation occurs in several of the PSM/RMP elements including SOP revisions, updating the ERP,  Lock-Out Tag-Out procedures,  PHA  revalidation, MOC process and hot work permits.  

4.11  Contractors:

Contractors conduct specialized delivery, maintenance construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Sea-3 has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur while they are working at Providence terminal.  

5.  Five-year Accident History:
 
Sea-3 has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases at our other similar terminal.  They have had no accidental release over the last 5 years.  Sea-3 has implemented release prevention programs, to prevent an accidental release of substances regulated under 40 CFR Part 68 which could resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  

6.  Emergency Response Plan:

Sea-3 maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to remediate (deal with) accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notifications or local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the emergency response plan is updated to reflect any changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified.  A copy of the ERP plan is provided to and coordinated with local emergency responders to improve the community response shoul

d an incident occur.   Sea-3 conducts annual emergency response drills to ensure our program is implemented and safe.

7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Sea-3 has made and documented numerous changes to improve the safe operations during the construction and recommissioning of the previously idle terminal.  Recommendations for changes to improve safety arise from process hazard reviews, program audits, incident investigations and employee suggestions to improve the safety of the operations at Providence Sea-3 terminal.  All recommended safety changes will be addressed and implemented as needed.
